title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that franchise business relationships are a significant and growing part of the American economy, replacing traditional small business ownership. However, there is a lack of reliable data on the number and operation of franchise businesses, as well as investigations into franchise failures. The lack of reliable statistics on franchise businesses is highlighted, with a large amount of potentially misleading information being provided in promotional material. This inaccurate data is often attributed to Federal Government agencies and outdated reports from before 1987. The purpose of this Act is to provide accurate statistical information about franchising to prevent franchisees from suffering losses due to false or misleading information. The purpose of this Act is to provide accurate information for prospective investors to make informed decisions about investing in a franchise business. SEC. 3. NATIONAL FILING AND DATA COLLECTION. Filing of Franchise Disclosure Documents-- All individuals or entities selling franchises must file a copy of the disclosure document with the Commerce Department. The document must be the most recent version. The franchisor must file the most recent version of the disclosure document with the Commerce Department, as well as the most restrictive version provided to prospective franchisees. The disclosure document must be filed annually with the Commerce Department as per regulations. The Department will provide copies to Congress, FTC, and other agencies upon request, and establish procedures for public viewing. It is illegal for franchisors to make false statements in advertisements or disclosure documents. Franchisors are prohibited from implying that the Commerce Department or any Federal agency has reviewed or approved their disclosure document. Data collection and publication are also regulated. The Commerce Department will establish procedures for collecting and publishing statistical information on franchise ownership and practices within 240 days of the enactment of this section. The principal source of data will be the disclosure documents required for franchise opportunities. The Commerce Department will establish categories of statistical information for annual data compilation on franchise ownership, including total numbers of franchisors, types of franchise businesses, annual growth, turnover in ownership, and franchise failures. They will consult with Congress, the Federal Trade Commission, and other relevant organizations. The Commerce Department will work with relevant organizations to identify additional categories of statistical information for data compilation and analysis related to issues of public interest or regulatory concern. This information will be obtained from disclosure materials filed in accordance with regulations and other public sources. The Commerce Department will collaborate with organizations to identify more statistical information for analysis on public interest or regulatory issues. This will include periodic questionnaires of franchisors or franchisees to supplement data in disclosure documents. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, based on information gathered from disclosure documents and the Business Census. The report will be submitted to Congress annually. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices annually, which will be available to the public through the Superintendent of Documents. SEC. 4. CENSUS DATA ON FRANCHISE BUSINESSES. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census, consulting with the Federal Trade Commission and other organizations to establish criteria and collect data. The Bureau of Census will submit a report to Congress within 280 days, detailing the most cost-effective and accurate methods to collect statistical information on franchise businesses for the Business Census. SEC. 5. RULES, REGULATIONS AND FEES. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to make rules and regulations to implement the Act, including classifications, adjustments, and exceptions as deemed necessary. Additionally, the Secretary can collect a filing fee. The Secretary of Commerce can collect a filing fee from individuals or entities required to file under the Act to cover costs incurred by the Commerce Department. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "advertisement" as a communication circulated to the public in connection with a franchise sale, and "disclosure document" as a statement required by the Commission or an offering circular prepared according to guidelines. The North American Securities Administrators Association, Inc., or its successor, defines "franchise" as a continuing commercial relationship where a franchisor grants a franchisee the right to offer goods or services. The franchisee must offer goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark and adhere to quality standards set by the franchisor. The franchisee must offer goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark and operate under the franchisor's name. The franchisor provides knowledge, expertise, and trade secrets to the franchisee. The franchisor provides knowledge, trade secrets, and assistance in the franchisee's method of operation. The franchisee must operate under the franchisor's name and offer goods/services associated with the franchisor's trademark. The franchisee must make a payment or commitment to the franchisor, other than for goods at wholesale price, as a condition for starting a franchise. This includes subfranchises or any commercial relationships based on representations. The terms defined in the text include franchisee, franchisor, person, and subfranchise. Franchisee is a person granted a franchise, franchisor grants a franchise, person is a natural person or legal entity, and subfranchise involves paying a franchisor for the right to sell franchises or provide goods/services to franchisees.
